The reviewers’ interrater agreement was deemed perfect (Cohen κ=0.96) [24].Results
Search Results
As shown in Figure 1, we identified 935 records by searching 7 electronic databases.
On the basis of these judgments, the risk of bias because of the randomization process was rated as low in 12 studies (Figure 2).
According to these judgments, the risk of bias because of deviations from the intended interventions was low in 20 studies (Figure 2).
Accordingly, only 9 studies were rated as having a low risk of bias in the measuring the outcome domain (Figure 2).
Accordingly, the risk of bias because of the selection of the reported results was considered low in 15 studies (Figure 2).
The results of the 9 studies were meta-analyzed as shown in Figure 3 [28-36].

A meta-analysis of the results of the 5 studies showed no statistically significant difference (P=.27) in the anxiety levels between the exergame group and the no intervention group (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.63 to 0.18; Figure 4 [36-40]).
Therefore, we included the results of all these measures in the meta-analysis to form 9 comparisons (Figure 5 [41-46]).
The subgroup analysis showed that the effect of computerized CBT on anxiety was statistically different (P<.001) between adults and adolescents (Figure 6 [41-46]).

A meta-analysis of the results of these 3 studies demonstrated a statistically significant difference in the anxiety levels (P=.03) between the biofeedback game group and conventional CBT group, favoring biofeedback games over conventional video games (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.43 to −0.03; Figure 7 [49-51]).

The reviewers’ interrater agreement was deemed perfect (Cohen κ=0.96) [24].Results

Search Results
As shown in Figure 1, we identified 935 records by searching 7 electronic databases.
On the basis of these judgments, the risk of bias because of the randomization process was rated as low in 12 studies (Figure 2).

Accordingly, the risk of bias because of the selection of the reported results was considered low in 15 studies (Figure 2).
The results of the 9 studies were meta-analyzed as shown in Figure 3 [28-36].

Search Results
As shown in Figure 1, we identified 935 records by searching 7 electronic databases.
On the basis of these judgments, the risk of bias because of the randomization process was rated as low in 12 studies (Figure 2).
According to these judgments, the risk of bias because of deviations from the intended interventions was low in 20 studies (Figure 2).
Accordingly, only 9 studies were rated as having a low risk of bias in the measuring the outcome domain (Figure 2).
Accordingly, the risk of bias because of the selection of the reported results was considered low in 15 studies (Figure 2).
The results of the 9 studies were meta-analyzed as shown in Figure 3 [28-36].

A meta-analysis of the results of the 5 studies showed no statistically significant difference (P=.27) in the anxiety levels between the exergame group and the no intervention group (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.63 to 0.18; Figure 4 [36-40]).
Therefore, we included the results of all these measures in the meta-analysis to form 9 comparisons (Figure 5 [41-46]).
The subgroup analysis showed that the effect of computerized CBT on anxiety was statistically different (P<.001) between adults and adolescents (Figure 6 [41-46]).

A meta-analysis of the results of these 3 studies demonstrated a statistically significant difference in the anxiety levels (P=.03) between the biofeedback game group and conventional CBT group, favoring biofeedback games over conventional video games (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.43 to −0.03; Figure 7 [49-51]).

Results
Search Results
As shown in Figure 1, we identified 935 records by searching 7 electronic databases.
On the basis of these judgments, the risk of bias because of the randomization process was rated as low in 12 studies (Figure 2).
According to these judgments, the risk of bias because of deviations from the intended interventions was low in 20 studies (Figure 2).
Accordingly, only 9 studies were rated as having a low risk of bias in the measuring the outcome domain (Figure 2).
Accordingly, the risk of bias because of the selection of the reported results was considered low in 15 studies (Figure 2).
The results of the 9 studies were meta-analyzed as shown in Figure 3 [28-36].

A meta-analysis of the results of the 5 studies showed no statistically significant difference (P=.27) in the anxiety levels between the exergame group and the no intervention group (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.63 to 0.18; Figure 4 [36-40]).
Therefore, we included the results of all these measures in the meta-analysis to form 9 comparisons (Figure 5 [41-46]).
The subgroup analysis showed that the effect of computerized CBT on anxiety was statistically different (P<.001) between adults and adolescents (Figure 6 [41-46]).

A meta-analysis of the results of these 3 studies demonstrated a statistically significant difference in the anxiety levels (P=.03) between the biofeedback game group and conventional CBT group, favoring biofeedback games over conventional video games (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.43 to −0.03; Figure 7 [49-51]).

The results of the 9 studies were meta-analyzed as shown in Figure 3 [28-36].

A meta-analysis of the results of the 5 studies showed no statistically significant difference (P=.27) in the anxiety levels between the exergame group and the no intervention group (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.63 to 0.18; Figure 4 [36-40]).
Therefore, we included the results of all these measures in the meta-analysis to form 9 comparisons (Figure 5 [41-46]).
The subgroup analysis showed that the effect of computerized CBT on anxiety was statistically different (P<.001) between adults and adolescents (Figure 6 [41-46]).

A meta-analysis of the results of these 3 studies demonstrated a statistically significant difference in the anxiety levels (P=.03) between the biofeedback game group and conventional CBT group, favoring biofeedback games over conventional video games (SMD −0.23, 95% CI −0.43 to −0.03; Figure 7 [49-51]).
